The government thinks that your time is worth nothing. At least, that's the implication of this written answer in the Commons last week.

The UKip MP, Dr Bob Spink, asked the environment secretary "what estimate he has made of the average time per year spent by a household in sorting and recycling rubbish." An important question of course, for that time spent sorting items to be recycled is obviously a cost of such recycling schemes. The answer came back from Jane Kennedy, minister of state in the department, "No such estimate has been made".

An answer that means that, quite simply, we do not know whether recycling is a good idea or not. For we don't in fact know whether it costs us more to do it than we save by doing it ... for those who have imposed it upon us have not considered one of the major costs associated with doing it.

Starting from the very beginning: your time has a value. This isn't restricted to your working hours either: the time you spend cuddling your inamorata, building a model railway or in contemplation of a pint of Old Wallop has a value to you. That is why you do these things, because you value them. If, by law, we are going to insist that you give up some of that time, to do something we tell you to do, we need to value the time you're being forced to give up. Quite what value we can put on it is a little fraught. It might be that £10 an hour, something like the average wage across the country, is the right number. It might be £5.73 an hour, for that is the minimum wage, the figure below which it is illegal for you to sell your time. But it is some cash amount per hour, for you yourself have already decided that you'd prefer the cuddling, modelling or contemplation rather than working that extra hour for such a sum.

We'd also like to know how many hours you are being asked to give up to aid in the recycling effort, thus the question asked above. I've received a similar response when asking the same department directly: they don't know because they've never bothered to consider the point. There's almost no academic research on this either, the amount of time it takes to prepare to recycle. The best I've been able to find is something from Seattle, showing that it takes a household 16 minutes per week for a simple programme and 45 minutes for one including food and garden waste. We have some 24 million households in the UK, so for a simple system we're asking everyone to give up 6 million hours a week or around 300 million a year. At minimum wage this is a £1.8bn minimum cost of such a system. At the longer estimate of hours for a more complex system and using the average wage, we have a cost of £9bn. These are the numbers we now need to plug into our cost benefit analysis of whether we should in fact be recycling.

Now don't get me wrong, I'm not against all recycling: no one who has bought and sold scrap metal for a living would be so stupid as to say that none of it makes sense. But we do need distinguish between things it is sensible to recycle and things that it is not. Steel, aluminium, copper, yes, clearly so, these make profits even when all of the costs are included and profit is the market's way of working out whether you are in fact adding value in a process. There are also other factors that we might want to include on our benefits side, things that aren't taken account of in market pricing. Say, perhaps, the methane given off from landfills, even the aesthetics of landfills themselves. Fine, add away: then we can work out whether recycling a particular product in a particular way actually makes sense or not. We assign values to all of the costs and to all of the benefits, tot them up and if B is higher than C then it's a good idea. If C is higher than B then it's a bad one for it makes us poorer by doing it.

It's also true that wittering on about "saving resources" doesn't get around this point. For time itself is a resource, one with a value as above. Indeed, it's not a difficult argument to make that time is the only truly non-renewable resource that we have and thus one that we really don't want to waste.

Now I agree that there's a little of tilting at windmills to all of this. Our targets for recycling aren't actually something in the power of our own government to alter. They are fed to us from Brussels, for matters environmental are a sole competence of the European Union. Local councils will be fined if they don't meet the targets and there's an end to the matter.

However, a few more numbers. We were told in the Waste Not, Want Not report that waste disposal was costing us £1.6bn a year and that if we didn't do something this could rise to £3.2bn. We thus needed to recycle more and reduce this cost … but hang on; recycling more also imposes this huge cost of our time. So are we in fact saving resources at all by pushing out our plans to recycle ever more of our waste? Or are we in fact consuming more resources than we're saving?

Here at Cif there are enough environmental and green type authors whose knowledge and brains we can pick. I'm perfectly happy to agree that the numbers I've used for the valuation of our time are back-of-the envelope stuff: however, they're the only attempt so far that anyone has made at all for the UK, as above, even the government hasn't tried to calculate them. So the labour cost alone of a simple recycling scheme is some £1.8bn a year and of a more extensive one, of the type being rolled out, is perhaps £9bn a year. I would say that this is vastly more than any benefits that we receive from that process. It's greater than the resources saved, it's greater than any environmental benefit, greater than any reduction in transport or emissions, greater than any rational calculation of what we get back for what we're being forced to put in.

So how about it? Caroline Lucas, George Monbiot, Oliver Tickell, Mark Lynas, Tony Juniper – there are enough people around here who should be able to prove me wrong. How much time is required to recycle, how should that time be valued, what are the benefits (valued in money please, so that we can compare costs with benefits), whether those benefits are environmental or more direct and, finally, show us that the benefits are greater than the costs. Please do add in CO2 savings for example, using the Stern review's estimate of social cost.

And no, saying that we've a new state religion and that we should all be required to worship Gaia for an appropriate time each week won't cut it. Anyway, it should be easy to provide these numbers – even though the government clearly hasn't done a proper cost benefit analysis, surely those urging us all to recycle more will have done so – won't they?

Nick Clegg today warned of an "an economic 9/11" as he suggested that the crisis in the financial markets could breed conflict, instability and nationalism.

The Liberal Democrat leader called on the EU to "step up to the plate" as he criticised European governments for being slow to produce coordinated action amid a crisis whose risks were "borderless and global".

Recalling the Great Depression of the 1930s, which created the conditions for the resurgence of fascism and the outbreak of the second world war, Clegg said that he was infuriated that the generation of leaders now running Europe failed to understand that nationalism and protectionism fuelled instability.

Extremists might find sympathy among groups who felt themselves victims of "economic injustice", the former MEP warned.

In a speech made hours after the British government announced a £37bn bail-out of the banking sector, and following a weekend in which European governments agreed a coordinated package of measures to deal with the financial crisis, Clegg said the financial collapse could become the "engine of global insecurity" in the months and years ahead.

Clegg told an event organised by the Institute for Public Policy Research that united efforts to stabilise the global economy would prevent a gap opening up in which "extremists can compete".

"In our world, economic strength is power," said Clegg. "We do not yet know, when the dust settles from this crisis, where the power will lie. The financial collapse we are caught in may prove to be an economic 9/11.

"9/11 was a security crisis, with security implications. This is an economic crisis, but its economic and social-security implications are potentially no less profound."

Clegg said that the British bank bail-out announcement earlier today, which will see the government take a controlling stake of up to 60% in the Royal Bank of Scotland, in return for up to £20bn from the taxpayer, would hopefully begin to stabilise the market.

But he called for a greater "political will" within the European Union to provide supranational responses to a supranational crisis.

Germany, France, Italy and a further 12 European countries in the eurozone last night unveiled a comprehensive plan for salvaging their banking systems from potential ruin.

Clegg said today that the coordinated action at EU level, which he said had been "slow in coming", would have to be followed by more radical action, such as interest-rate cuts and more aggressive intervention, to remove the "massive toxic liabilities" at the heart of the banking system.

"We have seen European leaders agree to work together with their counterparts one day, only to take unilateral action the next," he said.

"Eurosceptics have argued, and will continue to argue, that Europe has little to offer at this time of financial crisis, that this is an Anglo-American problem that needs an Anglo-American solution. They are wrong."

Outlining a five-point multilateral approach to tackling the crisis, Clegg said that European countries ought to work to tackle inequality to avoid extremism.

"Extremists target vulnerable and marginalised groups," he said.

"They will only find sympathy for their cause if disaffected groups feel that economic injustice has pushed them right to the edge."

He rounded on European heads of government such as Brown, Angela Merkel, Silvio Berlusconi, and Nicolas Sarkozy, who he said did not "instinctively" share the values that European cooperation was built on.

"Their predecessors, the architects of the European Community, were driven by the traumas of world war two," said Clegg.

"They understood the need for national sacrifice for the wider ideals of peace, prosperity and democracy.

"They knew only too well that nationalism and protectionism fuel instability. But their successors need to learn these lessons anew. No one more so than Gordon Brown. Yes, he is calling for a unified European response to the crisis now and I support that, but it shouldn't have taken disaster to convince him that European coordinated action can be the only way forward. It infuriates me, as a politician with a lifelong commitment to Europe."

Clegg also warned that America's "enemies" might seek to capitalise on the superpower's economic woes.

The country had already lost its moral credibility due to the war in Iraq, he said. Now it risked losing its economic credibility too.

Listing North Korea, Russia and Venezuela, Clegg said that the American "empire" had many enemies waiting at its gate who "may seek to capitalise on the present upheaval".

Other proposals outlined by Clegg today as part of his five-point plan to restore economic security across the globe included overhauling global financial structures, such as the World Bank, building a green economy across Europe, a clear EU decision to avoid the lure of economic protectionism in response to the current turmoil, and a new regulatory framework for financial institutions across Europe.

I hope George Osborne was watching Gordon Brown and Alistair Darling's Downing Street press conference this morning. In complaining that Brown ought to be blamed for his part in the global financial crisis, the shadow chancellor seems, for once, to be missing the point. Think Port Stanley, George, think Falkland Islands circa 1982. Margaret Thatcher was much to blame for that crisis, but she emerged much stronger for it.

I'll come back to that. The test of the Downing Street duo's performance this morning and, as the crisis deepened over the past few days, is whether people watching got the message. To judge by the instant response, the BBC's James Landale, and the FTSE – which dipped slightly after rising 256 points on opening – they did.

Brown is well aware that taxpayers resent bailing out bankers who they knew were greedy but now realise were also incompetent. The American backlash hasn't materialised here yet – they do populism more readily than we do – but it could.

So he and Darling kept stressing that, while they don't want to run the banks - "we want to appoint directors who understand banking, not civil servants," said the chancellor – they do intend to curb bonuses and impose tighter regulation.

Good, but more important still, Brown focused on banks as a necessity of life – a "lifeline" to small businesses and home owners - not some "abstraction" or luxury which can be allowed to rot. Regrettably, this is true; they're like the utilities – water, electricity, gas or, more appropriate, sewage – I suggested here the other day. We have to keep the shit flowing.

Brown, of course, was in his element, like a pig in the aforementioned. All those dull speeches he has made down the years about greater international regulation are suddenly relevant; he was making another later today. And the three-point Brown-Darling plan to stabilise the system looks - looks - as if it will be a model for wider international action.

Fresh from their weekend visits to Paris (eurozone) and Washington (IMF) the duo were suitably modest about that too; if you want influence you should never claim credit.

In any case ministers are still paddling furiously under the water, their plans to curb bonuses, take ordinary shares instead of preference shares and to appoint directors all markedly different from the tone last week. But, as Darling pointed out, with the bankers now asking for so much money – "nationalise us, please, oh please" – it could be counterproductive to confine the option to non-voting preference shares.

Semi-publicly, as hinted at in No 10, ministers think the taxpayers' money may yield a profit for the taxpayer in the long run. That's far too speculative a calculation. We have horrors to get through yet, including a looming recession of uncertain length.

But Brown-Darling (Brarling?) even managed to sound optimistic about the medium-term future. Darling actually chuckled on Radio 4's Today when referring to what history might say. Hindsight is a handy gift, he admitted.

During the No 10 press conference he also fielded questions without waiting for the prime minister's nod, always a good sign. Brown mostly looked grim, but grim is the new black at present, so that's OK.

"Cometh the hour, cometh the man," some ministers are saying. Well, that's cheeky, since some of them wanted him fired a month ago and nothing has really changed, it has merely become obvious, even to ostriches.

Which brings me back to George Osborne's complaint in today's London Evening Standard, that we can't blame the crisis entirely on the reckless US sub-prime housing crisis and the credit crunch it precipitated. Brown screwed up too.

True enough. Brown rode along with City bonanza further than he should have done (so did the Tories); he also failed to keep public borrowing down in the good years, though he did – as he said again today – pay off £100bn worth of long-term public debt early on after 1997 when he was under pressure to spend it.

But a fellow grandfather, waiting with the kids in the dodgem queue at our local fair on Saturday, got the point better. "That bugger Brown has got away with it," he protested before reeling off the then-chancellor's mistakes. True, too, but so may be the "got away with it" verdict.

Osborne was looking forward to his 11th birthday – just weeks away – when the blood-stained Argentine junta seized the Falkland Islands on April 2 1982. At Westminster British ministers prevaricated until after the Commons had risen, then owned up. I remember it all well.

After the emergency Saturday debate - a shambles all round - Lord Carrington insisted on resigning as foreign secretary and the 40,000-strong Task Force was hastily assembled and sailed 8,000 miles south into winter storms just 400 miles from the enemy mainland. Disaster was widely predicted and only narrowly averted.

But Britain prevailed and got the Falklands back. The long-suffering Argentine people got their government back. So, inevitably, did we get ours. Watching it all from the press gallery I never shared the view that Labour would have won in 1983 but for the Falklands war. Michael Foot's recent "I was right" on the 2008 bank nationalisation suggests he still hasn't got what was happening, bless his literary cotton socks. Labour had made itself unelectable.

But Jim Callaghan and Denis Healey – the Brown and Darlings of the moment – were right to protest repeatedly that government inattention, cuts and complacency had allowed the invasion to happen. In the defence cuts of that winter, HMS Endurance, the navy's "trip wire" vessel in the region, was withdrawn, leaving just 50 squaddies at Port Stanley - who duly surrendered when faced with overwhelming odds.

Worse, in the run-up to April 2, Callaghan, his ex-foreign secretary turned SDP defector David Owen, and the old imperial warhorse Sir Julian Amery kept warning Thatcher and her ministers in the Commons that the junta of General Leopold Galtieri was planning an invasion. They were brushed aside.

The junta had taken the Endurance decision as a green light. There would be a brief fuss and Britain would acquiesce. The Argentine public would forgive their mass slaughter of Peronists and leftwingers. They had captured las Malvinas from the gringos!! The anti-colonial UN would forgive.

Truly, as Jorge Luis Borges remarked, this was like two bald men fighting for a comb. But our bald Boudicca won and became the Iron Lady. Lord Franks investigated, rightly found fault, but exonerated the government in the famous last three paragraphs of his report. History is usually written by the winners. It was then.

I realise that blog wits have made the connection and are busy writing up Brown as Galtieri. They may be proved right, but their predecessors in the letters columns said much the same of Thatcher. So did Galtieri. Fortune favours the bold, and events have forced Brown to be bold. Others are following London's lead. It may end in tears. It may save Brown. We shall see.

We've seen the intricate cars, engines, bicycles and other machinations of civilization created out of cardboard by artist Chris Gilmour: bafflingly accurate and detailed for the imprecise medium. Artist Mark Langan, in contrast, creates sculptural works that are inspired by the form of cardboard itself, celebrating its grooves and textures. This work demands a kind of respect and awe for its material, which the artist collects from his own neighborhood.

Langan does not use any computer rendering to visualize a project: he sketches it the old-fashioned way, by drawing it out on a piece of paper.

Each piece is built through a process of cutting, layering, and sealing with a non-toxic glue. For a more sculptural texture, the artist will run his cardboard through a paper-shredder and make it into a putty with glue and water.

A completely self-taught artist, Langan dedicated himself full-time to his corrugated masterpieces after being laid off from an office job.

Some of the pieces are more overt proponents of the green lifestyle than others: one pieces says "Waste: it's what haste makes" while in another, Uncle Sam declares "I want YOU to recycle" (above). Most of the works, however, are elegantly trimmed celebrations of a cast-off material. It's the grown-up version of playing with cardboard boxes.

The thought preoccupies me more and more as each day passes: "What on earth should I do with all the banks that I now own?" As the global financial crisis accelerates and deepens and I assume ownership of an ever-longer list of banks and building societies, the question has grown in urgency.

Matters are not made easier by the fact that I am not completely sure how many banking institutions I actually do own just now. I also have an uneasy feeling that whatever answer I come up with, it will be utterly out of date by the middle of this week. It is quite possible that the majority of the key British banks will shortly be transferred to me.

Now at this point pedants will object that, in reality, I share the privileges of bank ownership with the rest of the British people. This is perfectly true. But the government repeatedly stresses the importance of strengthening "responsible" share ownership and ministers have been publicly critical of the failure of existing shareholders to hold their overpaid and incompetent managers sufficiently to account. So, naturally, I want to be sure that I can live up to my new responsibilities as a very modest stakeholder in the new publicly-owned banks.

Others will object, in an irritating, worldly-wise fashion, that the nationalisation of the banks is not really "public" ownership at all. They will point out that the government's nationalisation of the banks is only a form of temporary state ownership intended to save the bacon of the very rich people who until now have owned and (mis)managed these institutions so that they can be handed back to them or to their like once the public has paid for the whole, vast mess to be cleared up.

This, I acknowledge, may well prove to be the case. But for now (and that "now" may prove longer lasting given the global nature of the crisis than the government would like to believe), we have to make public ownership of the banks a success. Which is why the more we, the public owners of the banks, can agree on what our banks should not be permitted to do in future and what they should be required to do, the better.

Let us start with a few immediate, practical steps. We should require all the chairpersons and the principal executives of the failed banks and other financial institutions to resign – now. There should be no question of "golden parachutes" either. Moreover, parliament should immediately set up an emergency standing committee to interrogate the bankers and financiers involved in this crisis about how it was that they brought us to the brink of an economic catastrophe. Criminal investigations should also begin into those bankers and financiers suspected of fraud or other forms of malfeasance – including culpable neglect. Where the evidence exists, the bankers should be brought before the courts. Where proved guilty their assets should be seized to help pay for the astronomic losses their actions have caused.

Now some may think these proposals a little harsh – or they may even suspect some subversive, anti-capitalist ideological motivation. I would only point out that all of the above steps have already been urged by Republicans and Democrats of impeccably pro-capitalist lineage in the US. Indeed, in many cases this kind of action – including FBI investigations – has already begun. Surely New Labour would not like to be thought less publicly-minded than the Bush administration in ensuring that those responsible for this worldwide disaster are brought to account?

It should not be difficult to agree on what our publicly owned banks should be prevented from doing in future. This should include not trading in derivatives and other "financial products" about which none of them have the remotest understanding. Obviously the network of public financial regulation should be stretched to cover all financial institutions as well as all their activities on and off their balance sheets.

We should not be too negative in devising a new approach for our banks. It is clear that banks will have to work – for the foreseeable future – in a very different environment to that in which deregulated, "smash and grab", short-term priorities provided the golden rules for the God-like City bankers. Our banks should rather be obliged to support the very different kind of sustainable economic development which will now be essential.

The global society's new economic priorities should, for example, also mean that our banks give far higher priority to supporting the not-for-profit or "third sector" enterprises which have grown up both at home and abroad in recent decades. Our banks must also give priority to supporting enlightened forms of international economic development – such as Fair Trade, which may well come to play an increasingly important role in future.

In addition, the publicly owned banks could be instructed to use their influence with those they do business with to encourage, not discourage, trade union membership and enlightened equal opportunities policies. Apart from anything else, workers are an invaluable source of expert intelligence on how their enterprises are being managed, something which our publicly owned banks will be able to benefit from now.

Ultimately, it would not be surprising if some important banks were not so much "nationalised" as "internationalised", especially where support for the crisis-hit financial sector crosses national borders in the European Union. This could turn out to be a very fruitful form of European public ownership. It should encourage we, the owners, together with the trade unions and other civil society interests, to hammer out a longer term sustainable economic and social strategy across Europe and – maybe sooner rather than later – the world as a whole.

UK advertisers slashed marketing budgets more savagely in the third quarter of 2008 than at any time since the IPA's Bellwether report was launched nearly a decade ago.

The latest Bellwether report - a key indicator of the health of the UK marketing industry - was published today for the three months to the end of September.

It found that even internet ad budgets - a perennial star performer in the survey in recent years - came under pressure during a period that began with fears that the UK was sliding into recession and ended with a global financial crisis.

Advertisers elected to hold internet ad budgets steady in the third quarter, the weakest growth rate seen in seven years, "contrasting with the robust growth seen in previous quarters", the report said.

Overall, the report found that only 12% of UK companies reported an upward revision of marketing budgets in the third quarter, while 35% reduced ad spend.

This was the fourth successive quarterly reduction in UK ad spend recorded by the Bellwether report and "points to a marked deterioration in business conditions since the summer", it said.

Hardest hit were budgets for "main media advertising", including TV, radio and press advertising.

Bellwether's "all other" category, which includes PR, events sponsorship and market research, also saw record downward revisions.

"I doubt these gloomy results will come as a surprise to anyone," said Moray MacLennan, the president of ad agency trade body the IPA.

"In light of current headlines, the biggest surprise may well be that 12% of companies' budgets were revised upwards."

Companies attributed the cutting of budgets to lower-than-anticipated sales and profits - in turn reflecting weaker consumer and corporate demand - as well as growing concerns about the economy.

The latest downward revision in the Bellwether report indicates that UK companies are having a crisis of confidence in the state of the economy - unsurprising given the ever deepening financial crisis engulfing Europe and the US.

Just 8% of companies were more optimistic about prospects for the UK advertising industry than they were three months ago, compared with 69% that are now less optimistic.

When asked about the prospects for their own companies, 13% cited greater confidence in performance than three months ago, against 54% who are now less confident in the outlook.

"The slump in the Bellwether marketing budget and financial prospects data indicate a severe worsening of business confidence," said Chris Williamson, the chief economist at business information company Markit, which produces the report for the IPA.

"[It also shows] the rising impact of the credit crunch on the real economy, as companies rein in spending in the face of poor sales and growing fears over the economy."

Williamson added that the Bellwether report was consistent with other data showing the UK economy contracting in the third quarter "raising the possibility of the UK falling into recession".

The Bank of England was given more leeway to cut interest rates today as producer prices continued to fall in September, indicating that factory gate inflation may have peaked.

The Office for National Statistics said that producer output prices fell 0.3% in the month to September after dropping 0.7% in August. They fell to 8.5% in the year to September from 9.1% in August and a peak of 10% in July.

"The further retreat in producer output and input prices in September reinforces belief that underlying inflationary pressures have peaked even though annual consumer price inflation could well have climbed to 5.0% in September," said Howard Archer at consultants Global Insight.

Producer prices are seen as an early warning signal of inflationary pressure in the shops.

"The softer producer price data will facilitate further interest rate cuts by the Bank of England, although the timing and extent of these will be heavily influenced by financial crisis developments and the extent to which these are feeding through to hit economic activity. We expect interest rates to be cut by at least another 50 basis points before the end of the year, very possibly as part of further coordinated central bank action. We currently forecast interest rates to fall to 3% on 2009, but they could well come down further still," added Archer.

The Bank slashed 50 basis points off rates last week in its first emergency cut since the aftermath of the 9/11 terrorist attacks, leaving them at 4.5%.

Alistair Darling today said British taxpayers would benefit from the government's decision to pump up to £37bn into the Royal Bank of Scotland, Lloyds TSB and HBOS in an attempt to prevent UK banking meltdown.

After weekend negotiations, which continued through last night, the Treasury unveiled an unprecedented banking rescue plan earlier today.

The scheme will see bank bosses facing a crackdown on pay and bonuses, and shareholder dividends will be frozen.

The government will take a controlling stake in RBS in return for up to £20bn from the taxpayer.

Alistair Darling told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that total ownership in RBS, through a combination of ordinary and preference shares, would be 60%, with the figure for HBOS 40%.

The chancellor refused to speculate on how long the state ownership of bank shares would continue, but insisted the move to stabilise banks was an investment that would benefit the taxpayer.

"There is every reason to be confident that, as we go through this, the British taxpayer will get his money back," he told the BBC.

"There is a distinction between what we have done here and the borrowing that governments incur on a day-to-day basis.

"These conditions just now are exceptional and extraordinary and it is right that the government supports the economy ... but I am very mindful of the fact that the government needs to keep lending under control."

Asked when the state shares would be refloated, he said he did not think it "would be wise to speculate on when this is going to happen".

"We will do whatever it takes for as long as it takes," he added. "Ultimately, we want to return the banks to private sector because I don't think the government can run them in the long run."

Questioned on whether nationalisation meant all deposits would be protected, Darling said: "Given the stakehold we have in this bank, that sends a pretty clear message."

He said RBS and HBOS would continue to be run on a commercial basis and at arms' length from the government.

The government had been forced to act because the banks had no other way to get the money they needed to stay afloat, he added.
"Our intention is stabilisation and reconstruction," he said. "That is the objective, and that is what I intend to see through."

Darling said other countries should take similar measures to deal with what was a "truly global problem".

"We are living in extraordinarily turbulent times," he said.

"As long as governments the world over are prepared to take decisive action ... I think there are good reasons to believe that this will be seen as a very significant step along the way to getting through this."

He admitted that lessons needed to be learned on both domestic regulation and the international stage.

"The regulation system needs to face up to the global consequences," he added.

Normally, Proceeding and Unrestricted With Without Title 2008, by Gelitin
Psycho Buildings, Hayward Gallery, London

For many the concept of a boating lake in an art gallery is obscene: galleries are a place for quiet contemplation. Yet the hour-long queue to board a boat at the Hayward shows otherwise - even those accustomed only to painting and sculpture seemed to have embraced Gelitin's perplexingly named installation art.

An unstable set of stairs leads you up to an equally rudimentary platform: the marina. Plywood is stuck together with Polyfilla and foam-filled water cooler bottles amazingly providing suitable flotation. The boats are also made from simple, "found" materials, perhaps harking back to the arte povera movement of the 1960s, and feel as though they could have been knocked up in a few Sunday afternoons by father and son.

From the filled-in tray of an outside sculpture gallery, we have a view of London. The four boats are sandwiched between the Festival Hall, the Shell building and the rest of the Hayward, many feel not the most attractive of buildings (although like a small minority I feel that the Hayward is not a brutalist monster but a building of beauty). Gelitin, the Austrian arts four-piece, have made this with parodic intent, intending to bring a tranquil lake to the hubbub of the city, and it most certainly juxtaposes with the buildings around: the distant soundtrack of trains chugging and car horns beeping only adds to the effect.

They have brought with them one of the romantic lakes of their home country and placed it in the centre of London. Yet one feels as though there is more to Gelitin's typically humorous work than just combining surreal serenity with aggressive architecture. They have singled out art's famous lakes; Seurat's Bathers at Asnières, Dalí's Metamorphosis of Narcissus. Or perhaps the floods have finally come to London and we are trying to escape; global warming has taken its toll and we have to frantically row away.

Have you ever thought you'd like to help young women free themselves from all that male-driven cultural conditioning, and instead learn to love themselves for the people they are inside? Fred Wolf, the father of two girls, has let it be known that he harboured just this ambition. So he was knocked out when Columbia Pictures offered him the chance to fulfil it.

His was to be the privilege of directing The House Bunny, a wacky but heart-warming comedy about an alumna of the Playboy Mansion who finds fulfilment through self-realisation in the world beyond its walls. Her journey, Wolf hoped, might inspire his own beloved daughters.

Not, of course, that there's anything wrong with life as a bunny-girl, at least in this film. The Mansion depicted in The House Bunny is a near-paradise of camaraderie, fun, joy and love. A former inmate, Izabella St James, provided a less favourable account of life inside (complete with curfews and weekly assessments) in a book called Bunny Tales, published in 2006. Nonetheless, we shouldn't be too surprised that the film paints a somewhat rosier picture.

For Columbia and the Playboy guys came to an understanding. The film-makers were provided with access to the real Playboy Mansion, even to the very tabernacle that is bunnymaster Hugh Hefner's bedroom. The octogenarian Hefner, who's shown as treating his charges with unfailing warmth and concern, is played by Hefner himself. Fortunately, he manages to bring to the role all the charm, benignity and compassion that it seems to require.

Understandably, the film's heroine, Shelley (played by Anna Faris), is having the time of her life in his temple of bliss. Nonetheless, Wolf's mission cannot allow her to remain in thrall to male desire, however benignly it's manifested. So he plucks her from the Mansion's bosom and flings her onto the path to self-discovery in our own less cloistered world.

Almost immediately, she stumbles into what's effectively a mirror-image of the Playboy Mansion. It's a sorority house peopled by ugly, nerdy and grimly unsexy bluestockings. The film's central contrivance is that she'll teach them how to scrub up and get laid, while they'll teach her how to find her inner self. Unfortunately, the former exercise proves more persuasive than the latter. The ugly ducklings do indeed take wing under Shelley's tutelage; but her own reward for spiritual metamorphosis turns out to be the heart of a care home manager so dreary and right-minded that even the wizened, spectral Hef begins to seem attractive in comparison.

In the end, the Playboy Mansion's undiminished allure far outshines the dubious appeal of the brutish world beyond its bounds. On the latter's mean campuses, women may indeed create their own essence, but it's far from clear that the effort involved is worth the price it exacts.

Well, you have to hand it to Hef. He knows a thing or two about publicity. There's already a hit reality-TV show called The Girls of the Playboy Mansion, and a biopic is on the way. According to Hefner, Robert Downey Jr is interested in playing him, whatever Hollywood's normally sanctimonious elite may think of his line of business.

Believe it or not, the arrangement that brought us The House Bunny required Columbia to pay Playboy, rather than the other way round (Between the Lines can exclusively reveal). Hef was paid a further sum for his admittedly passable acting.

Let's hope that the director's daughters do indeed find the film that's resulted instructive. Sadly, however, it may impress the little Wolflettes less with the desirability of female empowerment than with the power of product placement.

Instant summary

Persuading the public: After Brown announced the outline of his bail-out package last week, the reaction at Westminster was almost universally positive. But Downing Street quickly picked up evidence suggesting that the public at large was far less impressed by the prospect of so much taxpayers' money being shelled out on the banks. Today Brown was trying hard to persuade people that the package really is essential. Banks were a "lifeline", he said.

Bonuses: Promising a clampdown on bonuses is an essential part of this strategy. Brown was more explicit on this than he was last week, and he repeatedly called for a new approach to bonuses. But, when questioned about this, Darling confirmed that the "no cash bonus" policy for a nationalised bank like RBS will only apply to board members, and that more junior bankers could still be allowed to pocket large sums.

Brown was also evasive when asked about pay-offs to executives who are leaving. He said Sir Fred Goodwin, the RBS chief executive, won't be walking off with a golden parachute, but he did not rule out other executives receiving enormous pay-offs. There's considerable anger in parliament and among the public at large at the prospect of bankers being "rewarded for failure", and it's not clear yet whether the Brown conditions will be enough to assuage this.

The future's bright: In some ways, Brown's most interesting comments were the ones he made about the long-term future of the economy. He said that with the global economy set to double in size over the next 20 years, there's going to be a lot of banking business that could come to London. It's a bold argument to make on a day like this, but Brown understands global finance better than most of us and it will be interesting to see whether people believe him.

Rock of stability: This was the phrase Brown used to describe the role of government at a time of financial instability. Perhaps it's not the best phrase. "Northern Rock of stability", a colleague joked.

At a Reform roundtable breakfast last week, Vince Cable MP, the prolific and much-revered Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman, warned of a new wave of economic nationalism arising in response to the current economic crisis. People are rediscovering government, he suggested, but not in a good way – instead of looking for creative and innovative leadership, there is increasing demand for state intervention and a danger of returning to 1930s protectionism.

Particularly over the last week, a number of governments have demonstrated signs of this "every man for himself" attitude, not least in Europe. Wednesday's coordinated interest rate cut was a welcome exception to this, but it isn't enough.

This isn't a British crisis, it isn't a European crisis, it isn't even an American crisis – this is a global crisis and, despite unique causes, circumstances and events in each country, our response will be stronger and more effective if we work in concert with other leading economies.

The growing clamour for state intervention – in the markets, in banking, in every aspect of our economic wellbeing – is both understandable and, perhaps, overstated; Peter Riddell pointed out in the Times that "comparisons with past Labour commitments to nationalisation are alluring but misleading since ministers will not run the banks". But there are some extremely important issues around regulation and protecting the taxpayer.

Boris Johnson came under fire last week for saying that "you cannot regulate your way out of a recession". He's right, of course, but the political situation is such that the public demand for assurances that this won't happen again needs to be heeded. Whatever decisions are made over the coming weeks and months, it is essential the government doesn't use the crisis, intentionally or inadvertently, to stifle the prospects of a bounceback in the financial sector's health.

Similarly, with the taxpayer spending £25bn to £500bn (depending on how you count it) on Britain's banks, it is important this public investment is protected. The initial omens look good – indeed, with luck, there is every chance the taxpayer could make a profit. But in finalising the details of the agreement, it is essential that the public purse is protected.

Whatever the short-term implications for debt, tax and spending, it is crucial that we do not allow a quick fix to turn into a financial hangover that will plague the next generation.

The Film

Breakfast at Tiffany's (1961) is a film by Blake Edwards from a story by Truman Capote. The film is remembered as providing a signature role for Audrey Hepburn, along with Roman Holiday (1953) rather than, say, The Nun's Story (1959). Henry Mancini's song, Moon River, performed by Hepburn, was awarded an Oscar.

The film has proved enduringly popular. The story of Holly Golightly combines romantic comedy with the polished sophistication of New York's upper east side. The relaxed nonchalance of the main characters exemplifies the style of New York as the centre of a chic, cocktail-hour glamour. This was perfectly in tune, at the beginning of the 1960s, with the kinds of images being produced by NYC's Madison Avenue advertising creatives to support the emergence of a credit-fuelled form of leisure society based on aspiration-driven consumption.

Accordingly, the figure of Holly Golightly may be understood as an enduringly powerful cipher for this kind of benign social mobility.

The Girl

Fashion is, nowadays, probably the most highly developed branch of popular semiotics. A raft of magazines provides clues, on a monthly and weekly basis, as to the cultural value of certain shoes, bags and frocks.

Back in the 1950s, before Breakfast, the fashion system was basically a couture industry that supplied hand-made garments for the social and aristocratic elite. The ready-to-wear retail phenomenon was unknown. The conservative fashion press in America chose its models from the eastern seaboard WASP elite. The daughters of European aristocracy were especially favoured for modelling with their old world and old money associations.

The photo shoots were studio based, static affairs, which showed these exquisite girls in ball gowns and cocktail dresses. The elaboration of a consumer society with a mass-market fashion system would require, it was clear to strategists, a different kind of model and a different kind of dress. The new woman would by dynamic, autonomous and relaxed.

Within the film and fashion system, Audrey Hepburn was positioned as a kind of mid-point transition between the cool, aristocratic, sophistication of Grace Kelly and down-home, keen-as-mustard charm of Doris Day.

In this context, it's worth itemising the Audrey Hepburn look in detail

The LBD: The classic little black dress by French couture house Givenchy was the pass partout of cocktail sophistication. Its relative simplicity gave it practical convenience that allowed women to move effortlessly between the different dress codes of work and evening wear.

The Rocks: The eponymous Tiffany and Co. supplied the jewellery. Tiffany's are part of the mythology of the aspirational American dream, supplying diamonds, silverware and engagement presents to the American elite since the 1850s. Beyond the jewels, their store, located on Fifth Avenue, with their distinctive pale blue wrapping has become synonymous with American retail sophistication.

The Shoes: Audrey Hepburn was a great shoe model who popularised the kitten heel. This shoe, like the LBD, allowed the easy transition from statuesque glamour to dynamic action. The shoe had just enough heel height to be both practical and elegant.

The Cigarette Holder: Probably the only item that, some fifty years later, is questionable. Back in the 1960s, the cigarette companies were still able to promote their products as sophisticated by association with Hollywood.

Together these elements combine, in a powerful and compounded form of signification and around the screen personality of Audrey Hepburn, to provide a dynamic and relaxed re-invention of the It Girl for 1960s Madison Avenue.

The City

The relatively small island of Manhattan provides for a wide variety of social geographies. The Little Italy, Chinatown and Hell's Kitchen areas are well known to cinema audiences. More recently, the upper east, and west, sides have become a staple of Woody Allen's neuroses-driven plot lines.

Breakfast inhabits the same social geography, but without the therapy. The film and its protagonists are untroubled by the pathology of excessive consumption that has characterised Fifth Avenue in last couple of decades.

Sex and the City

It's pretty obvious from what I've said that Breakfast can be understood as a prototype for the hugely successful Sex and the City. Indeed, Audrey Hepburn's position as poster girl for the SATC generation has become secure.

It's no coincidence then, that as the SATC franchise has developed, the fashion press have relentlessly promoted Hepburn as a role model and style icon.

The Poster

The minimalist design of the Breakfast poster effectively concentrates attention on the semiotic construction of Holly Golightly's screen persona. Only the cat and the rain soaked clinch allude to anything beyond a round of cocktail parties.

In recent years, this poster has become a staple of vintage film poster auctions. Apart from the obvious attractions of Hepburn, the popularity of the poster rests entirely on it expressing, some fifty years later and across a global mass market, the zeitgeist of a consumer-driven pursuit of material sophistication.

Audrey Hepburn

It's worth pointing out that Hepburn was an actress and that the role of Holly Golightly didn't necessarily reflect her own personality and taste.

Hepburn was born in Belgium and was connected to minor European aristocracy. Her experiences during WW2 gave her a sense of perspective from which to judge the fashion and film industries. From the mid-1950s onwards, she was an effective ambassador for the UNICEF.

With continuing exceptional instability in the global financial markets, the government is today taking decisive action, by implementing the comprehensive set of measures it announced on October 8, to make commercial investments in UK banks and building societies to help stabilise their position and support the long-term strength of the economy.

The overall aim of these measures is to support stability in the financial system; to protect ordinary savers, depositors, businesses and borrowers; and to safeguard the interests of the taxpayer. In summary, the measures intend to:

• provide sufficient liquidity in the short term;

• make available new tier 1 capital to UK banks and building societies to strengthen their resources permitting them to restructure their finances, while maintaining their support for the real economy, through the recapitalisation scheme which has been made available to eligible institutions; and

• ensure that the banking system has the funds necessary to maintain lending in the medium term through the credit guarantee scheme available to eligible institutions in relation to new short and medium term debt issuance.

The authorities have continued their detailed discussions with the institutions who confirmed their participation in the recapitalisation scheme last week. These institutions committed in aggregate to increase their total tier 1 capital, either through their own actions or, where requested, through support from the Government's recapitalisation scheme in the form of preference and ordinary share capital.

The government is making capital investments to RBS, and upon successful merger, HBOS and Lloyds TSB, totaling £37bn.

Following the completion of these capital investments, each of the above institutions will have a Tier 1 capital ratio in excess of 9%, well above international minimum standards and at a level that should put them on a strong footing for the future.

All participating institutions are eligible to take advantage of the government's credit guarantee scheme. The Debt Management Office is today announcing the general arrangements for operating the scheme. Further details relating to fees, the period under which guarantees will be issued and the application process can be found in the Market Notice which is being published by DMO at: www.dmo.gov.uk.

As part of its investment, the government has agreed with the banks supported by the recapitalisation scheme a range of commitments covering:

• maintaining, over the next three years, the availability and active marketing of competitively priced lending to homeowners and to small businesses at 2007 levels;

• support for schemes to help people struggling with mortgage payments to stay in their homes, and to support the expansion of financial capability initiatives;

• remuneration of senior executives - both for 2008 (when the government expects no cash bonuses to be paid to board members) and for remuneration policy going forward (where incentive schemes will be reviewed and linked to long-term value creation, taking account of risk; and restricting the potential for 'rewards for failure');

• the right for the government to agree with boards the appointment of new independent non-executive directors; and

• dividend policy.

The recapitalisations are designed to enable participating banks to achieve prudent but efficient capital structures. The government intends to create a new arms length body to manage the government's shareholdings in recapitalised institutions on a professional and wholly commercial basis, and seek to effectively realise value to the taxpayer. Transparent arrangements will be put in place to ensure that any role for the government in relation to investment decision-making is clearly defined. The government is not a permanent investor in UK banks. Its intention, over time, is to dispose of all the investments it is making as part of this scheme in an orderly way. To reflect the implementation of the scheme, the government will tomorrow announce a revised debt remit for the Debt Management Office. Further information is available at: www.dmo.gov.uk.

The measures the government is announcing today support stability in the wider financial system, and protect the interest of taxpayers, depositors and savers.

The government has informed the European commission of the schemes. The government stands ready to provide support through the schemes to all eligible institutions, on the basis of the conditions set out in its announcement last week.

The government is continuing to collaborate internationally to stabilise and strengthen the global financial system, following the meetings of G7 and G20 finance ministers and the IMF on Friday and Saturday. Other countries have announced measures to stabilise their own financial systems.

In parallel with other central banks, the Bank of England is today announcing expanded swap lines with the US Federal Reserve and that the Bank will supply dollar liquidity to the banking system against collateral at a pre-set price with no fixed limit on the amount. The Bank will continue to take all actions necessary to ensure that the banking system has access to sufficient liquidity.

With the first successful implementation of the schemes announced last week now completed, the government has taken decisive and extraordinary action to support the banking system during this period of exceptional financial turbulence, and to strengthen the system for the future as markets stabilise.

Further to my posting on the gloomy set of September circulation figures for national newspapers, I am now able to cast some light on the marketing side. I mentioned that News International's titles were doing better than their rivals, but I was unable to obtain information about comparative marketing spends by the groups.

Well, I still haven't been able to do that with any accuracy. However, in making the attempt, I did turn up some facts that are certainly worth noting.

Newspapers' television marketing spend in September was way down on what it was in the same month in 2007. The daily titles enjoyed boosts from only eight major TV promotions compared to 13 last year, while the Sundays had to make do with 13 TV promotions compared to 19 the year before. Several papers had no promotional support of any kind.

Owners have always been sceptical about the enormous sums required for marketing, especially the cost of TV advertising. The cost of securing sales spikes is often - very often - disproportionate to the outlay.

But the gradual retreat by some groups from TV to support promotions is also counter-productive. There is, after all, little point in a paper giving away DVDs and CDs unless people outside the title's core audience know about them.

And all this before the real effects of the global financial crisis kick in. Though people are anxious to know what is happening to the banks, and their own money, there is little sign of them buying more newsprint. Television and the net appears to be the media of first choice.

Riding with us in our RV near his office in Culver City last week, a silver-haired Tom Hayden says with a hint of irony, but not a trace of resignation - "I am just an old politician."

Forty years ago, Hayden stood as the voice of youth. He was a founder of Students for a Democratic Society, participated in the civil rights movement, and became a leading anti-war activist, traveling to North Vietnam with his future wife, Jane Fonda. He was one of the Chicago Eight, charged with inciting riot at the 1968 Democratic Convention (where I and another reporter had the dubious honor of bailing him out of jail).

Unlike some other young revolutionaries of his generation, Hayden didn't turn into a cynic or a conservative when the radical agenda of the 1960s and 70s gave way to the Reagan Revolution of the 1980s. Instead, he participated in progressive politics in Southern California, serving the state assembly and senate for nearly twenty years and working with local grassroots groups.

Hayden believes that the 2008 presidential election is far more than just another horse race between two men, or even two parties.

"The movement for Barack Obama is a genuine social movement inside the trappings of a presidential campaign," he says. "I think the Obama movement will produce the next wave of social activism in America for the next 20 or 30 years, whether he wins or loses."

In an essay endorsing Obama in the California primary last January, Hayden wrote: "Today I see across the generational divide the spirit, excitement, energy and creativity of a new generation bidding to displace the old ways. Obama's moment is their moment, and I pray that they succeed without the sufferings and betrayals my generation went through."

In a sense, Hayden tells us, both Sarah Palin's and Barack Obama's candidacies represent different apocalyptic visions of the future. For Palin and her followers, the rapture will be their reward when Christ returns to earth to gather up the faithful. For Obama's youthful supporters, a grimmer fate awaits them, with no money for college, no decent jobs, no rights, and a world brought to "the edge of extinction" by global warming - unless we change course now.

Hayden thinks that African Americans never believed whites would vote for a black man - and now that they have, many fear that Obama will be killed.

"We have to elect him and we have to protect him ... I have no doubt there are a lot of people in this country who are planning to shoot him, and there is a climate being generated to whip them up ... But he's got tools as well. He's got protection. He's got grace."

And Hayden himself is looking toward the day when this historic campaign achieves its goal.

"I'd like to see those Obama girls playing on the White House lawn," he says.
